Award.AwardTitle: Structural-functional characterization of a hyperactive antifreeze protein
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding the research of Dr. Krisztina Varga and Dr. Daniel Levy from the University of Wyoming to structurally and functionally characterize a hyperactive insect antifreeze protein. Antifreeze proteins are produced in several organisms that live in cold climates and contribute to their resistance to freezing. They bind irreversibly to the surface of ice crystals and inhibit their growth, however, the exact mechanism at the molecular level is not fully understood. The investigators will determine the structure of the antifreeze protein, examine its water binding properties, and investigate its mechanism of freeze inhibition in live cells. The results of this research will provide a better fundamental understanding of molecular processes characteristic of antifreeze proteins interacting with ice and expand their practical applications, for example, in protecting foods from damage by freezing. The project will have a broader impact by providing opportunities for underrepresented groups of graduate and undergraduate students to participate in scientific research, many of them being first generation university students from rural areas. The project will be integrated into outreach programs for community college, high school and grade school students.

This research will probe the structure and mechanism of action of the hyperactive insect antifreeze protein ApAFP752. The research will provide a better understanding of how antifreeze proteins interact with ice and provide cryoprotection to organisms that live in cold environments. The approaches are comprehensive and combine biochemistry, NMR spectroscopy, and confocal microscopy for both in vitro and in vivo studies and will utilize the synergy of the expertise of the investigators in these areas. This research project will be undertaken to (1) structurally characterize the antifreeze protein by NMR spectroscopy, (2) explore its water binding properties and interactions (e.g. hydrogen bonding), and (3) investigate its cryoprotective mechanism in Xenopus live cells. The comprehensive approach will provide unique insights into the underlying molecular mechanism of cryopreservation.

This project is co-funded by the Experimental Program for the Stimulation of Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Antifreeze proteins are specialized adaptations by certain organisms, including fish, plants, fungi, bacteria, and insects that live in harsh, cold climates. AFPs contribute to freeze resistance by binding to the surface of ice crystals and preventing their growth, thus lowering the freezing point of water. Despite considerable efforts over the past several decades, the exact mechanism of ice-binding and ice-growth inhibition at the molecular level is not fully understood. This is an important problem to pursue as the lack of understanding of ice-binding and ice-growth inhibition has hindered development of effective cryoprotection techniques and applications of antifreeze proteins.

The goal of this project was to investigate the mechanism by which the antifreeze protein from the desert beetle Anatolica polita protects against the damage typically inflicted by cold and to explore its potential applications in cryopreservation. We have determined the structure of the protein using spectroscopic techniques, characterized its ice and water binding, and investigated its potential as a cryoprotectant for human skin fibroblast and Xenopus eggs and embryos. The protein exhibits a highly disulfide bonded beta-helical structure consisting of six repetitive 12-amino acid loops with a flat surface that has good complementarity to the ice surface. Our data has provided further insight into the structure-function relationship of beta-helical insect antifreeze proteins. The ice and water binding properties of the protein were pursued by employing a wide range of spectroscopic and calorimetric techniques. We found that the protein decreases the freezing point of water and inhibits ice recrystallization (i.e. crystals restructuring into larger crystals) during temperature fluctuations. We also investigated whether the antifreeze protein can confer cryoprotection to cells that are otherwise sensitive to freezing. Frog eggs and embryos microinjected with purified antifreeze protein exhibited reduced damage and increased survival after a freeze/thaw cycle. Additionally, the antifreeze protein moderately increased the survival rate of human skin fibroblast cells relative to a control. The results of this study are an important step towards understanding the elementary processes involved in protein-induced cryoprotection and will facilitate the expansion of applications of ice-binding proteins in medicine, the pharmaceutical industry, and agriculture.

The PI's and co-PI's laboratories have provided great opportunities for underrepresented groups of students to participate in scientific research at the University of New Hampshire and the University of Wyoming. Both institutions are public universities that serve students from a wide range of backgrounds, many of whom come from rural areas. Graduate and undergraduate students in the PI's and co-PI's groups received valuable training that prepares them for their future careers in science. Students have learned biochemical methods for protein expression and purification, NMR spectroscopy, confocal microscopy, and Xenopus model systems through hands-on, thorough training. The PI has participated in a wide range of synergistic activities including mentoring individual high school students in her research group during the summer and mentoring the Central High School SMART team in Cheyenne, WY.
